chunks.en: Because my code level is trash, I don't dare to open-source the project
I've written quite a few projects, but behind the glamour is garbage code.
I don't know what level I need to reach before I can open source.
Don't worry, the fact that you realize your code is garbage already puts you ahead of most open-source developers.
This idea is wrong.
Open-source projects are a process of mutual learning and improvement.

chunks.en: Others can see good ideas in your project, and you can see excellent code in others' commits.
@kaiki #5 Actually, open source is not just about releasing the source code; open collaboration is also part of open source. It's time to learn environment management and decouple things;

chunks.en: Regarding how to get started with environment management, you can open a clean virtual machine, then clone your project, record the process of building the project, process all the things that can be scripted or even deleted, and write a template for the things that are strongly bound to the system, and add it to gitignore, for example, have an env.template, and tell the user in the readme to copy out env.prod, env.dev etc. to use, and add env.prod, env.dev etc... to gitignore. ğŸ‹ï¸ When you understand the principles of this decoupling operation, collaboration will be easily solved.
Me, who left garbage code in the Norwegian underground: ğŸ˜‚
Idea is more important than code.
It's okay, if it's useful, you can open source it; even code snippets can be open-sourced.
---- From a noob who just copied a gist

You can first register a new GitHub account, open-source it and see. If the project is popular, tell others that you are the author. If the project is unpopular, what does it matter if the code is bad? Anyway, not many people will see it. ğŸ˜‚

@Tumblr The most common trouble I encounter is when I send my project to others, they can't deploy it, or there are environmental differences, and I basically write the code based on my own environment and needs. To make it run normally for others, I have to rewrite it repeatedly, and I can't even find where the problem occurred.
I feel that those programs that are written to be 'out-of-the-box' are amazing. I don't know how I can achieve that.
@cmdOptionKana My GitHub account was blocked. Driving at the same time as open-sourcing is not allowed by GitHub. ğŸ˜“
Most open-source projects are also a mess. Besides, closed-source projects are even more disgusting. Everyone knows it, so there's nothing to be embarrassed about.

chunks.en: @kaiki Managing env, and doing various compilation configuration scripts, is both simple and troublesome, depending on the needs; in addition, open-source projects that meet your own special needs don't usually get contributions. It's never too late to consider it when you encounter someone raising an issue.
Open source is also garbage, don't be inferior.
Open source is more about letting others discover the shortcomings and problems in your project. Collaborative development is secondary, or it only appears after the project reaches a certain scale.
Just enjoy the process. Actually, I also think that the VS Code plugin I open-sourced is not very well written (very garbage)... I originally just did it for my own convenience, hahaha.

chunks.en: @kaiki #5 If others can't deploy it, they may raise an issue, or they may study it themselves and give you a commit. Anyway, no matter how, your project will definitely add a solution to this "undeployable" part. Isn't this an improvement?
To say it arrogantly, "This is how I open-source, use it if you want, or get out" is right. ğŸ˜
As long as the code can run, there are many open-source projects that you can't run even if you follow the README.

chunks.en: Actually, if you read many open-source projects, especially those with a lot of stars, and read a paragraph or two, you will find that the code quality is not very good. There is nothing to be embarrassed about. The most important thing in open source is what it creates, what it solves, and what it proposes.
A particularly popular open-source backend management project, the code style and implementation details of that project will give you confidence after you read it.

The only thing to fear about open source is that no one will use it, which will lead to no motivation to update it. If someone uses it, the code will always be replaced with elegant code step by step.
It's okay, you can go and see those popular open-source projects, they may be even more garbage than what you wrote.
Code, as long as it can run, is good code.
